Award.AwardTitle: S&CC: Promoting a Healthier Urban Community: Prioritization of Risk Factors for the Prevention and Treatment of Pediatric Obesity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Urban communities are facing many challenges due to the increasing complexity of urban life, declining urban services and growing health and economic disparities. While diverse stakeholders are engaged in understanding and solving these issues, progress has not been commensurate with the effort, attributed partially to the limited collaboration and data sharing. The persistence of obesity disparities in early childhood is one example of the negative consequences of such isolated efforts. Obesity is a multi-faced health outcome. While some risk-factors for obesity are universal, others are highly specific to the community in which a particular child lives. As such, successful efforts to prevent and treat pediatric obesity depend upon integration of data from multiple community sources and systems. The overall objective of the proposed research is to develop an innovative data-driven health informatics system (Preschool Risk for Obesity Portal; PROP) that aims to promote comprehensive, efficient, and personalized obesity-related care for preschoolers living in urban communities. Through the data sharing and integration within the community and the development, along with the beta-test of PROP, the project has the potential to promote a healthier urban community. Through the data sharing and integration within the community and the development, along with the beta-test of PROP, the project has the potential to promote a healthier urban community. The approach taken could be adapted for older pediatric age-groups, adults, and to address other health disparity issues in urban communities.

From a technical perspective, the PIs will: 1) design innovative multi-level mixed effects machine learning methods and scalable algorithms that can precisely identify and prioritize a preschooler's personalized risk factors for obesity and 2) develop a data- and tool-rich online system dedicated to pediatric obesity. Specifically, design (Phase one) and proof-of-concept testing (Phase two) for the PROP algorithms will be completed in this exploratory work. After the successful completion, the second component of PROP (an eHealth intervention) will be developed in a separate, bigger project for efficacy trial (Phase three) and effectiveness research (Phase four). The significant intellectual merit of this project lies in the novel algorithms for information extraction and understanding from multi-scale, correlated, and heterogeneous datasets. The online system dedicated to pediatric obesity will be built for the rapid dissemination of core computational techniques to researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Obesity is a multi-faced health outcome. While some risk-factors for obesity are universal (e.g., excess caloric intake, high level of sedentary activity), others are highly specific to the community in which one lives (e.g., built environment, cultural norms related to eating, access to public transportation). As such, successful efforts to prevent and treat obesity depend upon integration of data from multiple community sources and systems. In this project, we developed an innovative health informatics system that aims to promote comprehensive, efficient, and personalized obesity-related care in urban communities.

In order to conduct the prevention, intervention and treatment for obesity, and risk factor analysis was implemented to identify and understand the underlying risk factors that are associated with obesity. Most existing methods usually aim at building a one-size-fits-all model to identify the risk factors at the population-level. However, this type of approaches does not take into the consideration of heterogeneity (e.g., the community factors) in the population. To overcome this limitation, we employed the framework of multi-task learning (MTL) to identify a ranked list of obesity risk factors for each subpopulation/community (task) simultaneously with utilizing appropriate shared information across tasks. Within the MTL framework, we implemented two tailor-made models, i.e., multi-task feature learning and clustered multi-task learning, to conduct obesity risk factor analysis. The former can find the universal risk factors for all subpopulations without sacrificing the uniqueness of each subpopulation. The latter uncovers the grouping structure and conducts multi-level risk factor analysis simultaneously. By synchronously learning multiple related tasks, MTL provides a paradigm to rank risk factors both at the community-level and the population-level.

In this project, we also collected data that allow us to explore how risk-factors for obesity during the preschool years may vary for families of preschool-aged children living in the city of Detroit vs. Metro Detroit (suburbs). Caregivers were recruited from the University-Parent Partnership (UPP) Co-Registry, a joint effort between Merrill-Palmer Skillman Institute, Detroit agencies, and its surrounding communities. UPP includes Detroit-area parents of preschool-aged children who have indicated they would like to be contacted about future research opportunities. Outcomes further our development of a questionnaire aimed at standardizing preschool obesity screening and comprehensiveness of this assessment to address all factors increasing obesity risk in this age-group.

In this project, we continued our practice of disseminating the research results in classroom teaching and educational outreaching. In addition to our systematic efforts of incorporating multidisciplinary research into the classroom learning, we established a novel MS program ? Data Science and Business Analytics in Fall 2017 and brought together faculty and expertise from engineering, business, and science to offer holistic interdisciplinary ?core? courses and allows specializations in data computing, advanced analytics, and data-driven business. The PI of the project is serving as a co-director of the new MS program. More information is available at http://engineering.wayne.edu/data-analytics/index.php

The program has over 100 students with a mix of working professionals from various industries as well as full-time students. The program is guided by a dynamic industry advisory board and brings real-world projects, consulting engagements, internships, case studies, and speakers into our courses. It is capped by an industry sponsored capstone practicum where students from all specializations collaborate to address challenging real-world projects from fortune 500 companies to startups and work both onsite and on campus to deliver impactful tools, solutions, and processes. Past and current sponsors include City of Detroit, Siemens, Quicken Loans, DTE Energy and multiple startups. Students are mentored for active participation in local meetups/hackathons and advisory board members provide valuable career guidance through informal campus residency sessions.
